title: 113_hr5786
content: The "Small Financial Institutions Regulatory Relief Act of 2014" allows certain loans held by small creditors to be included as qualified mortgages and exempts them from escrow requirements. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to exempt loans held by small creditors from escrow requirements. The Bureau will exempt loans secured by a first lien on a consumer's primary dwelling if held by a creditor with assets less than $10,000,000,000. Additionally, there is an increase in the small servicer exemption. SEC. 4. INCREASE IN SMALL SERVICER EXEMPTION. The Bureau will provide exemptions or adjustments for servicers with 10,000 or fewer mortgage loans to reduce regulatory burdens while maintaining consumer protections. SEC. 5. EXCEPTION TO ANNUAL PRIVACY NOTICE REQUIREMENT UNDER THE GRAMM-LEACH-BLILEY ACT. Section 503 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act is amended to include an exception to the annual notice requirement for financial institutions that meet certain criteria and have not changed their policies regarding disclosing nonpublic personal information. SEC. 6. Changes required to small bank holding company policy statement on assessment of financial and managerial factors. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System will revise the Small Bank Holding Company Policy Statement to apply to bank holding companies with assets less than $5 billion, not involved in significant leverage activities, and without a significant amount of public debt. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System will annually adjust the dollar amount in the Small Bank Holding Company Policy Statement based on the percentage increase in total assets held by insured depository institutions. Additionally, within six months of the enactment of this Act, proposed revisions to the Policy Statement will be published in the Federal Register. The debt-to-equity ratio allowable for small bank holding companies to pay corporate dividends and remain eligible for expedited processing procedures under Regulation Y would increase from 1:1 to 3:1. SEC. 7 amends the Federal Reserve Act to require at least 1 board member with experience in community banks under $10 billion in assets. This change applies to future appointments. SEC. 8 deals with the designation of rural areas. The Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection will establish an application process for designating rural areas under Federal consumer financial laws. Evaluation criteria will include factors used by the Census Bureau and the Office of Management and Budget for classifying geographical areas. The Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection will establish an application process for designating rural areas under Federal consumer financial laws. Criteria for evaluation will include factors such as population density, property eligibility for rural development programs, rural-urban commuting area codes, and a written opinion from the State's bank supervisor. A public comment period of at least 90 days will be provided for applications submitted. The Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection will make a decision on designating rural areas within 90 days after the public comment period. The Bureau may grant or deny the application and will publish the decision in the Federal Register with an explanation of the factors considered. Subsequent applications for designation may be submitted after a denial. The Bureau may deny an application for rural area designation, but subsequent applications can be submitted after a 90-day period from the denial.
